WRITING.TEXT:
Doc Rivers is an average coach who lucked into Danny Ainge trading for one of the best five power forwards ever and one of the greatest shooters ever. None of Rivers' teams won a first round series until Garnett showed up in Boston. And while his rosters in Orlando and Boston weren't great, he still had Tracy McGrady and Orlando never won a series with him.
Is he a good leader? Absolutely and I think he did a nice job with the Sterling stuff last year.
But he doesn't deserve to be mentioned among the best coaches in the league.

I agree with this. It amazes me how reporters and the average basketball fan will nuke Calipari and Kentucky for ruining college basketball, while giving guys like K, Self, Roy and (back then) Ben Howland a free pass.
And for what it's worth, I have absolutely no problem with coaches getting one and dones. It's a bad rule that can be exploited for wins. I'd do it. I just wish there was a consistent opinion about it on the guys who do it.
Duke deserved it with their play down the stretch, but it seems like it's becoming a common occurrence for great college basketball games to be marred by officiating. Just awful.

Marshall might not be the ideal fit there. He's one of my favorite coaches, but he strikes me as a guy who wants to be the top dog at his school. He won't be that at Texas or Alabama. Some media in the Midwest also think he's a bit weird personality wise, but I don't understand that. Coaches naturally are wired differently.

This didn't have to be a season-long arc, but I would have loved to see more of an internal struggle with Dexter in terms of who to follow: Harry or Brian. I think it would have been cool to see those dueling personalities (Angel vs. Devil) last longer than just one episode. Perhaps it could have come after the Season 4 twist.
I don't know....perhaps make Dexter "The Big Bad" for the finale season if you wanted to go in a completely different direction.
Knowing the NCAA, this is what they'll penalize North Carolina for while letting the academic fraud go.

First, I think it's unfair to call him a bad tournament coach simply because of the runs in 2008 and 2012, especially 2012. That team had no business getting to the national title game and it did. It won a lot of close games that year in the tournament and coaching wins in close games. I'd call him an average coach, but not a bad coach.
I think what's hurt KU's teams under Self over the years are a mix of things: Lack of a consistent conference rival (Texas was great in 2008 and Mizzou's 2012 pushed KU), perhaps coming out too tight in a lot of games and luck.
With luck, look at the VCU loss. VCU was 12-of-25 from three that day. KU was 2-of-21. You're not going to win too many games when your opponent is 30 points better than you from the three-point line. If KU finishes that game 6-of-21 from three, they win. VCU was playing some of the best basketball I've seen. Is that coaching? Maybe a little bit.
Bradley and Wichita State were cases of really young KU teams going against experienced teams. Outside of size, Wichita State had almost every advantage coming into that game. KU was one of the youngest teams in the country. The Shockers' core had played in a Final Four, finished a regular season undefeated and went to war with a Kentucky team that nearly won the title.
The Northern Iowa and Bucknell loses were inexcusable. KU was the best team in the country in 2010 and that tournament should have been their's.
I read something on the NBA reddit page about how Popovich takes the pressure off his team by telling them basketball doesn't mean everything. I'd be curious what Self's game-day preparation is like. I do think KU teams have a tendency to come out tight in the tournament. Usually that means the players have the wrong mindset entering the tournament. Maybe that's what Self can work on.
But overall, I'd take Bill Self over 97 percent of coaches out there. I think KU needs a rival where the game matters more than the standings. Time to schedule Mizzou or Wichita State? I don't know. Maybe hope Texas hires a great coach or Hoiberg stays at Iowa State?
Yay....yet another SEC school that has a coach better than Mizzou. If only Mississippi State would have hired a "true son" like Mike Alden did.

RECENTLY: I really thought Brian Shaw would work out as a head coach. Not so much. Maybe he still will, but certainly not with the Nuggets.
NOT SO RECENTLY: I thought the Spurs were done the year Memphis beat them as a #8 seed. Instead, they made three straight WCF, two conference finals and won a title. You can also argue last year's Spurs team was the best in the Popovich era, though the '07 squad has an argument.
I guess it was the Auburn win that finally sold the committee on Kentucky.

One of the biggest problems with Alden and basketball coaches is that he's a micro-manager of everything. It scared off some of the better candidates during his last two hirings.
I wasn't a big fan of Haith and I'm not sure he deserved an extension.
But if you let Haith leave, you must do better than a Division 2 head coach who built his D2 program through transfers, JUCOs, ect. He's never proven to develop talent from the freshman level. He was Norm's lead assistant during some of the bad years in the mid-to-late 1990's. He absolutely did not deserve the job and the fact some Mizzou fans think he did a good job this year is a good example why Mizzou's never made a Final Four.

With all due respect, what improved over the course of the year that makes it clear Kim Anderson is a better developer of talent? Kim did most of his damage at CMSU through transfers from Division 1 and JUCO programs.
I want the guy to work out, but I'm not optimistic about Kim.

Mike Alden deserves most of the blame for this. The original sin, of course, was hiring Quin Snyder over Bill Self and John Calpari.
Then, there was his brilliant decision to hire Mike Anderson over Bob Huggins. Now, I love Mike Anderson and I hope he does really well at Arkansas. But it was no secret Huggins was putting together a great recruiting class behind the scenes. If Mizzou hires Huggy, things are better.
After Mike Anderson goes home, he pulls Frank Haith out of nowhere, when Gregg Marshall and a few others wanted the job. This was before Marshall went to the Final Four, but it was clear he was building something at Wichita State.
Finally, he hires Kim Anderson, a Division 2 coach who was NEVER even a candidate at a school like Missouri State, UMKC and other area small Division 1 schools in the Midwest. The only reason he was hired was because he was a Tiger alum. Fact. Alden hired Kim Anderson and threw a bone to the older fan base and donors who are bigger Norm Stewart fans than Mizzou fans. Ben Howland, Brad Underwood and Chris Mack would have taken that job, from what someone close to the Board of Trustees told me. Yet, they hired a True Son Division 2 head coach.
I wish Mizzou would fire Alden before his retirement becomes official. He murdered the basketball program.
Considering Bradford is a member of the Cherokee Nation, this might score some points with Stephen A. Smith.

This kind of reminds me when the the Bulls blew up the team after winning its sixth title. A little bit different since the Niners didn't win the title during the Harbaugh era, but I think the results will be earily similar.
If OU hangs on to a 21-point lead against Iowa State and West Virginia doesn't lose an 18-point lead, OU is playing to break The Streak this weekend. Crazy how that works out.

While I loved Captain America: The Winter Soldier, I wish there would have been more to how Steve adapted to 2010-14. I think there could have been some nice realization that while some things changed for the worse in Steve's eyes (less patriotism, less connection between individuals), things also improved for the better - less racism, more accepting population to differences.
I know it may have added more time to the movie, but I think it would have been great to show him struggling with the time change, rather than just putting it off as a funny line with the checklist early in the movie.
God, the Colts are a perfect fit here.
Came in here to say this. Better yet, I'd love for them to beat Notre Dame in that game considering that's Jed's school.
Eh, I think the football game will be pretty boring myself judging by the last two decades.

I don't buy that Tattoo gate was orchestrated, but I do think there was communication between the Meyer and Ohio State camps during that scandal. Between Meyer's wishy-washy ending in Florida when he retired twice and the timing of how it all went down, I wouldn't be surprised if there was a wink and a nod type of deal between the two. It's amazing how those heart problems and migraines went away. Also, in terms of Ohio State having an interim head coach the year between Tressel and Meyer, I could see Meyer wanting to take a year off to let the NCAA settle with Ohio State.
And for what it's worth, I don't blame Ohio State at all if something like this happened. Urban Meyer is one of the two best coaches of the past 20 years and if you get a chance to land him, do it.

Season 2 by a hair over Season 1. I think both of those seasons are the only ones where it felt like every episode mattered, though I admit I would have loved to see Dexter having to make the choice of killing Doakes or not.
Lithgow was outstanding in Season 4 and the ending was the most shocking TV moment I've seen, but there were some flaws to that season that are often overlooked because of how good of a villain Trinity was.
Last week's loss must have knocked Kansas out of the Top 5.
Kim "no hats while eating" Anderson approves.
Yeah, we have no room to talk smack when it comes to basketball. Also not included in that is an 8 point loss to UMKC.
You might replicate this type of beatdown to Missouri very soon. Nolen's teams were fun to watch....it was one of the reasons why I was excited about Mike Anderson's hiring at Mizzou.

After a bad story about Mike Singletary came out, he accused someone on his staff of "being a rat." According to a Bay Area sports talk host, Harbaugh suspected there was a rat on his staff. (https://twitter.com/JohnMiddlekauff/status/566383965280280576)
One coach served on both staffs. He's the same one that was hired as the head coach. Gee, I wonder how he got the job.

Good read and a scenario that's not often mentioned with "what if" stories. Dr. J and Kareem would have been fun to watch for sure.
The one "what if" scenario I think about is if Orlando kept Chris Webber instead of trading him for Penny. Not sure if they overtake MJ's Bulls, but Shaq+Webber would have been very interesting.

Mizzou's football team has a really good chance of having more wins than the basketball team this season.
I guess that makes us a football school, so I can't answer this.
A lot of great coaching talent has left the world in the past week. RIP Tark the Shark.

Where do I start?
First, our coach is calling out his players because of the bad manners they are displaying. He's punishing kids for wearing hats while eating. He called out two players by name for showing bad "posture" during a post-game interview session and one of his priorities is how they enunciate words.
Missouri basketball: First in manners, last in the SEC.
Sadly, a lot of our fan base is eating this up because they are bigger fans of Norm Stewart than they are Missouri basketball. Some Mizzou fans would be perfectly fine running out five white kids from rural Missourah each night, as long as they "hustled" all the time.
Missouri fans have accepted sucking for a long time. The deification of Norm Stewart/Kim Anderson are great examples. Norm would be the sixth best coach in the history of Kansas Jayhawks basketball. He'd be a footnote there.

How any prominent loss from an SEC team means it's overrated, never mind the fact the conference still brings in the most top recruits and produces the most NFL talent most years. The amount of times fans brought up Oklahoma beating Alabama and Indiana beating Mizzou was absurd. The Mizzou loss was terrible, but it was not a reflection of the conference's 13 other teams.
Anyone wearing a Cleveland Browns jersey.

The development of young talent and the fact the Raiders beat the Chiefs and 49ers, two of the team's biggest rivals. The Chiefs victory began their downward spiral that prevented them from getting in the playoffs. The 49ers win was one of the final nails of the Harbaugh Era in San Francisco.
* Philip Rivers * Antonio Gates * Jamaal Charles * Derrick Johnson * Aqib Talib
I like the City of Lawrence. That's about it.

Kansas begins with a close win over South Dakota State. The next week, they are hammered by Memphis.
It's now basketball season.
Seeing this Tweet and the Mark Pantoni tweet makes me the biggest Michigan State fan who lives in Kansas. Go Sparty!

ELEPHANT #1: The prospect of the Raiders overspending and signing bad contracts with players. Having $50-60 million in cap-room is good if you know what to do with it. However, it's also an invitation to giving away money for guys who may not be in their prime any more. As much as Marshawn Lynch in a Raiders jersey appeals to me, the fact that's nearly 30 also scares me. A team like the Raiders has to pay a little bit more for a quality free agent due to how bad they have been lately. But hopefully they do not break the bank.
ELEPHANT #2: The fact Jim Harbaugh and other quality head coaching candidates rejected the Raiders. If the rumored contract offer for Harbaugh is true. he left a ton of money on the table. The Raiders have not had a quality head coach since Jon Gruden.
So, are Iowa State fans the only Big 12 fans that do not storm the court after beating KU?
Bill Self is playing the long-con here. Good move!
What kind of a world do I live in where the Raiders are making pretty good moves? Love this.

Nope. I still think it sucks. I'd understand the idea of passing the ball if you didn't have one timeout left. You run on second down and if you don't get in, call timeout. Pass on third down and on a potential fourth down, you have the Patriots playing the ultimate guessing game.
It's no guarantee Seattle gets in from there - see the Packers/Seahawks game - but your best player needs to touch the ball at least once in that final stretch of plays. Add in the fact Lynch almost got in from the 6 and it's even bigger no-brainer.
Agree. If Tony Romo threw that pass, Twitter would have broken down .
Promise kept.

This was the first time I watched Virginia this year. Very impressive team that definitely is on the short list of teams for Kentucky to watch out for. Bennett is a great basketball coach and the way that team plays together is fun to watch. Nice rebound win after a tough loss against Duke.

Nope. Judging quarterbacks by rings is stupid. No one talks about the game-winning drive he should have had against the Giants in the first Super Bowl. He's been in my Top 2 since 2008-09 with Montana.
And for what it's worth, the talking heads on ESPN would not be positive on him today if the Seahawks don't blow that game late.
The Triangle and 2 defense he ran on North Carolina in the 2012 Elite Eight is up there in his best moves. Roy Williams looked lost in the second half trying to adjust to that.

This doesn't match last night, but Popovich's decision to sit Duncan late in Game 6 in the 2013 Finals was bad. He's the greatest power forward ever and one rebound ends that series. The Spurs coming back to win it in 2014 kind of softens this mistake, but that was a bad move, especially coming from one of the three best NBA coaches ever.

And Bevell's play-calling could have been more physical too by handing the ball off to one of the best short-yardage backs in the NFL. He may be right about the wide receiver, but it's pitiful blaming him for it.

It's the "everyone is against us" mentality a lot of Boston fans seem to have. They complained for years and years about being cursed about the Red Sox, while Celtics, Bruins and Patriots were winning championships.

The argument about the salary cap era also benefits Montana in a way. Those great defenses he faced in the NFC - the Giants, Bears, Redskins and Eagles - remained the same. They benefited greatly from continuity and being in the same system all those years.

Brady is the best of this generation/era for sure. He will be unless Aaron Rodgers can get two or three more rings.
All-time, I still prefer Joe Montana. This is no criticism of Brady, but Montana played in an era where defensive lineman could hit the quarterback as hard as they wanted. Montana played in an era where defensive backs could be physical with wide receivers. Rod Woodson once said Dan Marino would throw for 100,000 yards in this era with these rules.
I don't like the idea of rings validating a player. In my eyes, Tom Brady's legacy would not have changed one bit if the Pats lost tonight. But for those who want to do rings, Montana was 4-0 in the Super Bowl and never threw an interception. Brady has now thrown four and it took him three attempts to win ring #4. Montana, while having great talent at the end of his tenure in San Francisco, won his first two Super Bowls without Jerry Rice. If you look back at his first Super Bowl team, it was not exactly stacked.
Montana and Brady both benefited from great coaches, so that part of the debate is out the window in my opinion.
I'll take Montana, but Brady definitely deserves to be at the table in this debate. It's down to those two, in my opinion, and you cannot go wrong with either. I just prefer the guy who played in a tougher era for quarterbacks. But I think those who say this debate is definitely over are incorrect. Both sides have great arguments and the answer lies in what you value more.

I thought he was going back to Seattle before tonight, but I'm 50/50 on him staying there or going back home to Oakland. Not getting the ball in that moment is a bitter pill to swallow.
I don't really know, but I do think the chances of him leaving tonight increased.

Yep....how crazy is it the Cowboys had only the third cruelest loss of this postseason? Any of those four are memorable losses and now they're just footnotes compared to Seattle and Green Bay. I still think Green Bay's was the worst considering all the missed chances, mistakes, ect. This was just one bad play-call.

When looking at it historically, I think it's in the Top 3 of worst Super Bowl losses - up there with the 18-1 Pats and the Norwood Bills. There's a reason Marshawn Lynch is called "Beast Mode." I think it's the worst call in Super Bowl history for sure. What's even more interesting is I wonder if the Pats would have conceded the score on the ground to save time.

I think they have the talent for sure, but I still think Jim Caldwell holds them back. His conservatism makes Mike McCarthy like like Don Coryell. Lost in that officiating controversy was the fact Caldwell's coaching performance was very bad.
Patriots fans will still find a way to claim Woodson is disrespecting Brady.

WRITING.TITLE: Former Kansas Libertarian Lt. Governor candidate says integrating direct primary care would help state save money

WRITING.TEXT: It's unknown about the Patriots having deflated balls, but it's clear that Richard Sherman has brass balls.

I'm curious if this is Chad Ford doing this or ESPN doing this. Ford, I believe, is one of the ESPN Insiders. That's a premium subscription deal. If ESPN edits his draft boards, they can promote it as "the most accurate" draft board on the Internet. Thus, they could make it easier to sell subscriptions to ESPN.
It'll be interesting if someone tries to dig up Kiper and draft boards from other sports.
Seattle's owner is not a buddy of Goodell.
"We are not the New England Patriots." ---- ISIS statement.

I would say SF/SEA in 2013. It did not have the craziness of SEA/GB or even MIN/NO, but I thought both teams played a very good game, turnovers aside. It was the climax of one of the league's best rivalries and it was damn good game. I also think it's clear those were the two best teams in the league.
Barnwell is learning well from Bill Simmons. Both are great writers and intelligent, but both are incredibly thin-skinned as well.
Sean Payton believes Belichick should be suspended a full year without pay.

One thing I don't get is why the Patriots did this. They have absolutely owned Indianapolis since Peyton Manning left there. Indy was one of the weakest "Final Four" teams I can remember in a while. This is the sports equivalent of Nixon trying to sabotage a very weak field of Democratic candidates with the Watergate scandal.
Here's hoping one of New England's punishments would be banning TV networks from showing Robert Kraft 1,240 times during a game.

Both defenses stepped up for sure, especially Seattle's for keeping Green Bay out of the end-zone. I think Seattle beats Green Bay at least 7 out of 10 times if they play on a neutral field considering the Hawks played a terrible, terrible game on offense and still won.
But the narrative is rightfully placed on Green Bay's feet. I cannot recall a championship game where one team or coach missed so many opportunities. Green Bay kicks a field goal two times after a drive stalled inside the two. Most coaches go for it at least once. A Green Bay defender slides and gives up a potential "pick 6" or at least better field position. Aaron Rodgers throws two bad interceptions, including one to Richard Sherman in the end-zone. Bad decision. The onside kick. The screw-up on the two-point possession. The play-calling late in the game. Green Bay's defensive meltdown late in the 4th quarter and early overtime.
I think Seattle is the better team and they're my pick two weeks from now, but Green Bay choked. Sorry. This is a game they had to win based on Wilson's 4 interceptions. But Mike McCarthy had his "Grady Little Game" on Sunday. If McCarthy did not win a ring already, he may have been fired today.

Meanwhile, Mike McCarthy coached with deflated balls during the NFC Championship Game.
EDIT: Thanks for the gold! And sorry, Packers fans. It reminded me of Gruden's conservative coaching in the Tuck Rule Game and the year before against Baltimore. Hang in there!
I picked New England and New Orleans, so half right.

It's one of the two or three most devastating losses I've seen an NFL team take in the playoffs. There were about 10 plays where if just one went the Packers' direction, they win. I can't remember a game that had as many heroes and goats as this one did. And in the case of Russell Wilson, a goat becoming a hero.
Seahawks. Nothing against the Patriots, but I love the way they play with emotion, especially BEAST mode and the Legion of Boom. Plus, I enjoy the irrational hatred most NFL fans have for them.

Even though they were division rivals back in the day, I actually like Seattle. These Seahawks and the defense they play are not supposed to happen thanks to the rulebook being so slanted in favor of quarterbacks and the offense. Them repeating, especially beating Manning and Brady in back-to-back years, has to secretly piss off Goodell and the other NFL owners who want high scoring games.

Because Russell Wilson is a capable quarterback who knows how to throw? Part of the Tebow backlash was everyone, particularly Skip Bayless, for promoting him even though it was clear he was a bad quarterback.
Entering today, Wilson had the highest quarterback ranking in postseason history. I think that's one of the big reasons why Wilson doesn't get the "hate" Tebow does.

The game this reminded me of was the San Diego/New England playoff game from 2007. San Diego controlled that game most of the way and should have won. But dumb coaching and dumb mistakes from individual players cost them.
It's 2015....why are there even prostitution stings, any way? Just seems like a waste of resources and law enforcement manpower.
That's a good scene. Watching Season 1 again after you know the twists involving Rudy/Brian is fun. There are some fun things to look for when rewatching it.

LeBron James and Kobe Bryant might have the flash, the points and the marketability, but this is why Tim Duncan is the best player in the post-Jordan era in my opinion.
The guy took less salary to keep San Antonio a contender. He took less of a role to benefit his team. He's the most coachable superstar perhaps in NBA history. There are middle-school level games with him. He just wins.

WRITING.TITLE: Hospitals hope Kansas will follow recent red-state trend on Medicaid expansion

WRITING.TEXT: Another fact: This guy won a conference title with Jake Delhomme at the QB position and a playoff game with Tim Tebow as a starter. I get that Fox was conservative and he wasn't a great coach. But if a Denver cornerback doesn't make an all-time boner of a play against the Ravens two years ago, Fox might have made two Super Bowls in four years.
Amazing. Both coaches I'm sure had flaws....but when "Super Bowl or get fired" is the criteria, this league is getting out of control.

I think the two keys to this game is how Ohio State handles Oregon's pace on offense and if Urban Meyer and his staff commits to the run. They dirty secret in Oregon's blowout win against Florida State is that FSU was running the ball very well before the melted down in the 3rd quarter.
Not taking away from Oregon's staff, but I think Meyer will coach a terrific game. My gut opinion is he'll commit to the run, control the line of scrimmage and grind it out. I think this ends up similar to the first UA/UO game and it's a lower scoring game than most think.
Ohio State 28, Oregon 24.
Traffic might be backed up in New Jersey tomorrow.

New England/Seattle. Seattle having the chance to beat both Manning and Brady in a Super Bowl would be a fantastic story. If they did that and held Brady in check, that defense would have a legit argument as the best ever. The Bears and Ravens defenses beat bad quarterbacks in Super Bowls. Seattle would have knocked off the two best in the post-Elway/Marino era.
Perhaps, but let's say they win that Super Bowl against Baltimore. I would imagine tensions would be considerably less if they won a Lombardi. I could be 100 percent wrong, though.
That's one of the great what-if's in recent NFL history. Do the Niners' win at least one Super Bowl? Does Harbaugh stay there?
Good call by the officials there.
John Fox is going to get fired if Denver loses this game, but most of the blame deserves to be placed on Manning and the Broncos offense. No urgency.
Yeah, Arkansas was very solid up front this season. Good things are happening there for sure!
Bielema's track record with offensive lineman going back to his Wisconsin time is impressive. Not surprised a talented lineman would want to play there.

This was Tuck Rule II in my opinion. Technically the "Right" call, but an absolutely garbage rule. Three moves and a dive for the end-zone = football move in my mind. If that's not a catch, I don't know what's supposed to be a catch.
That said, Aaron Rodgers was phenomenal in the second half. It shouldn't take away from the game he had the Packers would have had 3 minutes left to respond.
How will the Chiefs replace all those touchdowns he had this year?
I love this Tweet from Bill Simmons: https://twitter.com/BillSimmons/status/551903885778903040
I'm so sorry, Detroit fans.

"College" from the first season of The Sopranos. That is the episode that got me hooked. "Pine Barrens" was stellar, but if you asked me to pick an episode of the show to make someone a fan, I'd select that one.

If laughing makes me a bad guy, I'm a bad guy.
They were not making fun of rape or the woman who was raped. They were taunting Jameis Winston and made fun of one of the single dumbest chants in sports. I thought it was funny and clever. Sue me.
Plus, a side bonus: It indirectly brought attention to the case and how the Tallahassee Police Department screwed up the investigation. That was not the reason they did it, but it brought the subject back up and it's worthy to discuss.
I find it fascinating that these kids will receive more punishment for this than Winston received for this entire investigation.
Congratulations to Minnesota on a great season! Kill is doing good things at that program and I hope to see him stay there for a while.
Another fair point. This is hilarious.
Agreed. I think he's trying to get his way on something, whether it's David Blatt or a roster move.

Or....he is being Machiavellian and sending a message about the coach/franchise? He and Wade probably talk regularly. He knew those cameras were there. I think this was intentional and not some "slip up" that was discovered.
This is the NBA equivalent of the Zapruder film. I've watched it seven times already.

Al had his issues, but he doesn't deserve to be included in a comparison with York. Al made a lot of bold hires in his hay-day and actually did win three Super Bowls. York ran off the best coach the Niners had since Bill Walsh. (Sorry, but Siefert was asked to not wreck a corvette.)

I think Season 5 gets a bad wrap from a lot Dexter fans, though not necessarily here. I like the idea of him helping out Lumen as a way to exorcise his own demons about losing Rita. I liked the Lumen storyline and as someone who had a good friend raped violently years ago, I enjoyed it each time one of those guys were murdered.
I do hate the cop out they did with Deb at the end, but still a solid season that's above Season 6, Season 7, Season 8 and in my opinion, Season 3.

A wild thought I had....one I doubt would actually happen, but worth bringing up.
How about the other Harbaugh? Lost in the whole Ray Rice scandal was apparently a rift developing between the Ravens front office and the Harbaugh in terms of how to handle the Rice situation. The Ravens and John Harbaugh denied, of course.
But if the Raiders are willing to fork over $9 million to Jim Harbaugh, why not John Harbaugh? He's won a Super Bowl championship and outside of one year, he's made the playoffs every season he's coached. Even though they made the playoffs, that team is not as good as it was just a few years. No Ray Lewis. I think Flacco has proven to be unworthy of that contract.

Now, Al was losing it in his final years, so that contributed to the downfall. But the 49ers better have a plan and bring in a credible coach. Josh McDaniels does not fit that bill.

WRITING.TEXT:
They'll only jump recruiting wise. I think that's a given with Harbaugh's track record and what Michigan football is about.
What I'm curious about is the potential domino effect this has on the quality of conferences. I've long believed the single biggest reason the SEC became what it was is coaching. This started with Steve Spurrier at Florida, then picked up when Nick Saban was hired at LSU, Urban Meyer going to Florida, Mark Richt at Georgia (I know he hasn't won it all, but still a great record), Les Miles to LSU, Saban to 'Bama, ect. The SEC is what it is because of coaching. I don't necessarily buy the "warm weather means everything" argument. I think Nick Saban would win if he coached college football in New York City, Iowa, Idaho, ect. Oregon, Ohio State, Wisconsin and Missouri have all had 12-win seasons the past decade and they're in the cold. It's about coaching and vision of a program.
I think the Big 10 could be back if Michigan hires Harbaugh. Ohio State with Urban Meyer is very, very good. I like James Franklin to turn Penn State around down the road. Mark Dantonio has Michigan State playing great football. I actually think Mike Riley could be better than many think at Nebraska. Kill's doing some very nice things at Minnesota. I also think Harbaugh and Meyer will force programs to up their games and make big time hires. I could see Iowa making a run at Bielema, for example, in the next few years. Saban's presence in the SEC made the other schools ante to sign coaches and to keep them.
If Harbaugh lands at Michigan, the Big 10 profile will benefit in a big way. It'll still take a while to overtake the SEC, but the gap would close considerably with Harbaugh at Michigan.
That, and the Ohio State-Michigan-Michigan State triumvirate will make for some awesome rivalries and recruiting battles.

I live in Kansas City, so I've seen a lot of Chiefs games this season.
The keys:
- Make Alex Smith beat you. Alex Smith is a good quarterback, but the Chiefs have been at their best when Jamaal Charles and Knile Davis have carried the team on offense. On top of that, the Chiefs don't have any deep threats. Contain Charles and the rushing attack and the Raiders have a puncher's chance. I think Alex Smith is capable of putting the Chiefs on his back (he did in the playoffs last year), but make him do it.
- No turnovers. Last year, the Raiders turned the ball over seven times against the Chiefs. I think this Chiefs team is a lot better than last year's version. That's not gonna cut it against a playoff team. They've also had numerous, killer turnovers over the years against the Chiefs when they've played on the west coast.
- Special teams. The Chiefs have been very solid on special teams returns this season. De'Anthony Thomas is due to break one. Let's hope it's not against the Raiders. To win, the Raiders need to win the field advantage battle.
- Find ways to get to Smith. The two games Smith has really struggled in this year happened because the defense got to him big time. Whether it's winning the battles up front or calling creative blitz schemes, rattle him and knock the Chiefs' offense off rhythm. They don't have sexy stats, but the offense is efficient.

Actually, yes I do.
What if Mizzou hired Bill Self as head coach in 1999 instead of Quin Snyder? The three finalists for that job were Self, Snyder and some guy named John Calipari, who recently got fired from the NBA. Calipari pulled out of consideration at the last minute.
So many interesting parts to this:
1. Does Mizzou become the top program in the Big 12? Self's track record against Roy Williams makes me think it was possible. Self recruited a lot of guys to Illinois and Mizzou is a pretty similar program in terms of geography.
2. Who does Illinois hire in 2000? Does Illinois even sniff the Final Four without Self bringing in that talent? Do they somehow find a better coach who stays there for years and years? What if's go both ways.
3. Who does KU hire in 2003? Help me out here KU fans, but wasn't Self the slam dunk top candidate? Do they find someone who continues to win like Roy did? Do they hire a Matt Doherty/Steve Lavin type that sends that program into the ground?
4. Where is Self coaching today? While I'm a diehard Mizzou fan, I'm a realist and Mizzou certainly would not be Self's last coaching job. Does he take the Oklahoma State job when Sutton retires? Does he take over at Kentucky or Indiana at some point? Or, oddly enough, maybe North Carolina if Self took Mizzou to a Final Four before 2003? He said in his book that he wouldn't have left for KU if he was offered the job had he been Mizzou's coach. I could maybe see him pull a Pitino and take an NBA job and later be hired by KU if he failed in the NBA. But he certainly would not have replaced Roy.
I honestly think this is the biggest "what if" of the past 15 years in college basketball consider Self's success at Illinois and KU.

Kim Anderson
Strength 1: He has a history of winning. Is it in D1? Nope. But he's won a national title and he's won big games at his level. This suggests that he knows basketball and can coach well. That doesn't mean Mizzou will win a title or anything like that, but he has a pedigree of success.
Strength 2: I think his teams will be a lot smarter than those Frank Haith had. So I think he'll bring some fundamentals back to this team.
Weakness 1: No D1 experience. Bo Ryan demonstrated that you can go from one level to the next and do well. Still, it's a HUGE question mark and it's why I wasn't so excited about the hiring.
Weakness 2: I won't say this is a weakness necessarily, but can he recruit enough talent to compete against Kentucky, Florida, Arkansas, ect.? Haith was a good recruiter. Can Anderson and his staff bring in some talent?
_____
Mike Anderson (I'll pick Arkansas as Mizzou's SEC rival in basketball)
Strength 1: Defense. When his team has the right talent, but they can create havoc on defense.
Strength 2: He's good at stabilizing a program. I know most Mizzou fans don't like him now, but he took over a dumpster fire from Quin Snyder. Anderson did a nice job at making Mizzou respectable again and by all indications, he's a class act and he can recruit well. He's a good "Face of the Program" type and I think Arkansas will get good again.
Weakness 1: He's stubborn as hell. I loved the guy, but if he's coaching against a team with better athletes, he gets rolled all the time and will not adjust from his system. See what Bill Self and KU did to him most years when Mike as Mizzou. He's not great at adjusting his defense.
Weakness 2: His half court offenses were average to below average most years at Mizzou and whenever I watch Arkansas play, they seem to struggle there too.
That said, I still respect the job he did at Mizzou and thankful he coached there. Now Kim Anderson has to clean up a bit from the Haith Era .

Disappointed they didn't win, but I'm not in pain over the series loss. The Royals ran into literally the best pitcher in World Series history and settled on one of the best defensive plays in Game 7 history.
It's not like the series was decided on a Bill Buckner play. The bullpen didn't blow a lead in Game 7. There was no choke job. There was no weird fluky stuff like Steve Bartman or Bucky Dent.
The Giants were a pinch better than the Royals. If they played 10 times, I think they'd split them. Unfortunately, there are only seven games and the team with the best pitcher won.
I can't lose too much sleep over this loss.

Obviously no guarantee, but here's what I do:
1. Let Shields and Butler walk. I appreciate James Shields and what he did to help transform the culture. But the Royals are a small market team and I wouldn't give a 33-year-old pitcher a $100 million deal. I wish him well, but the Royals need to be thrifty with the $30 million they'll have to spend. Plus, I think a healthy Duffy and a more experienced Ventura would help fill the gap. Add in Vargas and Guthrie and you have most of the starting rotation from this year.
2. Make a run at a right fielder. They've mentioned Torii Hunter, but I'd prefer Michael Cuddyer. He's hit reasonably well at The K, averaging .280 with 13 homers in 58 games. Cuddyer wouldn't be a big, big bat. But he'd be a nice position upgrade. And I'd prefer him over Hunter due to age.
3. Look for another starter somewhere. Maybe a Brandon McCarthy? Don't know.
4. Look for a decent back-up catcher. Salvy Perez needs a reliable back-up after this year.
I know there's buzz about trading one of the members of the HYDRA bullpen, but I'd wait for the trade deadline. If the Royals are struggling badly, then swing a deal. However, that bullpen is too good to break-up until it needs to be. It needs to be a Godfather like offer to move any of them.

Even as a Royals fan, I definitely understand your point. However, I believe both the Giants and the Royals were built for the postseason and deserved to be there in the end.
Bumgardner is literally the best World Series pitcher ever and a short-game series allows the Giants to use him more. The Royals' bullpen this year was the most dominant baseball has seen in a long time. It almost was enough to win the World Series.
The postseason allows teams to shorten their pitching staffs, meaning the fourth and fifth best pitchers of the staff don't start unless there are injuries. I imagine teams with a great regular season record had fun when teams threw out their fourth or fifth best starters.
Plus, the Royals won 102 games in 1977 and failed to make the World Series. They won 97 games in 1980 and failed to win the World Series. Weird things happen in October and I'm not apologizing that the Royals made it in the series.

Before it started, the two World Series doppelgangers I thought this series could turn out like is the 2003 World Series or the 2007 World Series.
The 2003 World Series, like this one, featured a previous world championship team (Yankees, Giants) and a "What the hell" team (Marlins, Royals) that ended with the younger and unexpected team winning the title. I know there wasn't a Bartman situation for the Royals, but that Marlins team had a lot of comeback wins, late-inning victories, timely hitting, great defense and a couple fluky breaks like this Royals team has.
The 2007 World Series had a similar storyline, except this time the Cinderella was overwhelmed by the more experienced and better team. Admittedly, I had a flashback to the 2007 World Series after Game 1.
There's still a long way to go. The way this postseason has gone, I wouldn't be surprised by any outcome at this point.

Let the record show he never made the Final Four and he had his share of tournament flame outs. Norm would be the fifth best coach at KU with that record.
While I'm warming up to the Kim Anderson hire, the fact he was #1 on so many fans' lists (at least here in Kansas City) was depressing, especially with Howland, Gregg Marshall, ect. out there.
Remember Norm fondly. He had a good run at Mizzou. But he wasn't John Wooden or Bear Bryant. Let's not look back to the past when we're looking to the future. I wish Kim Anderson well, but if he wasn't a Norm Guy, he doesn't get that job.

I've went back and forth, but I'm leaning towards "work" for these reasons:
1. Everyone benefited. Bret got the big contract from WCW and had the best entrance into WCW possible. He was the most famous athlete in the world. Shawn Michaels got heel heat you can't buy and the title. Vince McMahon got more attention to his company and Bret's exit opened the door for Steve Austin to rise and for "Mr. McMahon" to become a great heel. Heck, even the ref is famous because of it. It was the perfect end for Bret Hart's "Hitman" character.
2. Vince had MANY opportunities to take the belt off Bret. Also, if I remember the timeline right, the contract negotiations were going on even before Bret won the belt that year. Why put the belt on him in the first place? Also, why not take the belt off of him before Survivor Series? Vince is too smart of a guy in my opinion to get himself into a jam like this, especially after the fiasco of the female wrestler who trashed his belt on Nitro.
3. The fact Owen stayed. I know Bulldog left, but if someone legitimately did that to my brother, it would be tough for me to work for Vince.
4. For years, Vince refused to let outside cameramen take photos around the ring. Somehow he decides to let a documentary film company go backstage, interview wrestlers, ect.? Come on.
5. The fact multiple wrestlers, including Lawler, Kevin Nash and others, suggest it's a work is telling to me. Lawler was part of the greatest storyline ever with Andy Kauffman and they kept that secret for 20 years.
I see both sides of the argument, but those are my five reasons why.

It reminds me of how Donald Sterling was only forced to give up his team after he told his girlfriend to not hang around with black guys, rather than giving up the team after he was proven to have descriminated against minorities.
Can we punish violence and actual actions more than words?

How I did it:
- I started walking two miles a day, hell or high water. Walking three straight weeks gets you into an exercise habit. After walking for three months and losing 50 pounds, I started doing TaeBo. After a year with TaeBo, I started doing Insanity, where I lost 100 pounds in seven months. Bottom line: Start slow, especially if you weighed A LOT like I did. Gradually increase the stress of your workout. I did not go to the gym once.
- I gave up liquid calories and stuck to water, tea and unfortunately, Diet Mountain Dew. Liquid calories pile up quickly.
- Keep track of your calories. Moderation is important. You can cheat here or there....but you can't go overboard.
- Find a way to keep your accountable. I used Facebook and my 1,000 plus friends. I celebrated milestones. I noted when I failed. Compliments, encouragement and help from friends goes a long, long way.

WRITING.TITLE: Theory on Jim Carrey's "The Majestic" --- Peter was Luke all along
WRITING.TEXT:
This movie has been popping up on HBO a lot lately. It stars Jim Carrey and takes place shortly after World War II.
Having watched it a few times this summer, I've developed a theory that Peter Appleton and Luke Trimble are one in the same.
Evidence:
1. Early in the film, it's mentioned that Appleton attended college via the GI Bill. The GI Bill was available for those who also served on the homefront, but it connects the fact that both characters were in the military.
2. Both characters had a connection to the movie industry. In Appleton's case, he was a writer in Hollywood. With Trimble, his family ran a movie threatre. If the Appleton/Trimble character suffered an injury during the war that resulted in a temporary loss in his memory, perhaps going to Hollywood and working on movies happened because of his childhood, similar to how the Pirates of the Sahara movie poster reminded the character of his life in Hollywood.
3. There's a conversation between the doctor and Luke's dad during the town gathering scene about how Luke had been missing for years and years and lived another life. I thought this was hinting towards an ending revealing that Peter was Luke all along. However, I'll just use this as a hint regarding my theory.
4. Luke's body was never found. Again, while I'm sure there were plenty of soldiers who were never recovered, this is an important basic fact in the theory.
5. The whole town was convinced. A few townspeople had suspicions, but the fact that everyone bought into it gives this some credibility.
6. Soldiers suffered from Dissociative Amnesia in real life and was first diagnosed following World War I. So, again, there is real life evidence backing up this theory.
**TL;DR: Peter was actually Luke the entire time ---- and Peter was the life he had all the years he was missing.**

WRITING.TITLE: Excluding your own team, what free agency move disappointed you most as an NBA fan?
WRITING.TEXT:
Obviously fans of those teams who lost out on the LeBron, Carmelo and Bosh sweepstakes will be upset that their teams couldn't land them.
But what about moves across the league that you wish would have happened just as a basketball fan?
To me, I wish Carmelo Anthony would have signed with Chicago. Melo has never been on a team that was considered a favorite to win the championship. Chicago with Melo-Noah-Rose, along with a nice supporting cast, was going to be the favorites in the East IMO. It would have been interesting to watch Melo respond to that pressure. He played on some nice Nuggets team, but Denver was never considered a strong favorite to win a title. Neither have any of the Knicks teams he played on. Kobe, LeBron, Wade, Bosh, Duncan (and his teammates) have all been on teams that were favored to win titles. Not Carmelo.
Plus, having LeBron, Carmelo and Paul George in the same division could have set up some great rivalries between Chicago, Cleveland and Indiana. I hope Carmelo does well with the Knicks because the league is more fun when the Knicks are good, but I wish he would have signed with the Bulls.
I'll take the easy way out and pick the Portland/Houston series. Just fun basketball and those two teams were matched up so evenly.
Just like the Super Bowl and the NBA Finals, the best team beats the team with the best player. That's the theme of the 2014 sports calendar year.

WRITING.TEXT: Oakland A's: I respect Billy Beane and they are the small-market franchise I wish the Royals could be at some point.

- I thought the Spurs were finished after Memphis beat them in the postseason a few years back. Instead, they've won two conference titles and if this team closes it out, you could argue this was the best Spurs team ever.
- I thought Spo wouldn't last in Miami and Riley would eventually run him off so he could coach LeBron. Instead, Spo's proven to be one of the best coaches in the league.
- And one to show my age: I thought the Bulls/Magic series in 1996 would go down as one of the greatest postseason series ever. That Bulls team was great, but the Magic beat them a year before and Shaq/Penny were in their primes. Instead, the Bulls sweep them.

This may not be necessarily answering the question, but I wish Magic would have been able to finish out his career on his own terms.
A lot of fans forget Magic retired at the age of 31, meaning he had at least five to six good seasons left in him. While he was older, he was still playing very well in 1991, averaging 19.4 and 12.5 assists. He also averaged 19, 12 and 8 against the Bulls in the '91 Finals without a completely healthy Worthy and Byron Scott. I still think the Bulls win the title that year, but it goes 6 or 7 with a healthy Lakers team.
But if Magic plays five to six more seasons, I imagine Jerry West would have found a way to build a solid roster around him. Perhaps the Lakers trade for Barkley instead of the Suns? How about Magic, Shaq and Kobe on the 1996-97 team?
A lot of what if's, but if Magic didn't get HIV, there may have been two more titles and three to four more Finals appearances in his column. If Magic retired with seven titles and 13 finals appearances, the debate between Michael Jordan and Magic Johnson becomes very interesting.
The 10-year anniversary of that championship team is coming up. Should be a nice reunion.

LaGuerta's death practically meaning nothing for Season 8. Her death should have been the catalyst for the main plot of Season 8 --- whether it was Dexter being on the run again; a season-long Dex vs. Deb plot (who takes the fall) or motivating Batista to pick up where she left off on her own investigation. After all, he was married to her.
There are things here or there I didn't like. I didn't like Hannah McKay. I wish Lumen could have lasted longer. I wish Brian's ghost would have hung around a little bit longer in Season 6.
But LaGuerta's death hardly being mentioned in the final freaking season of Dexter was unforgivable for me.

WRITING.TITLE: WANTED: Digital salesperson, 50 percent commission on all sales, thousands of leads available
WRITING.TEXT:
Edge Media Technologies is looking for an experienced salesperson to increase business for our network of local news Websites in Wyandotte County and Johnson County.
Edge Media Technologies publishes four Websites: The Kansas City Kansan (KCKansan.com), The Gardner Edge (GardnerEdge.com), The De Soto Edge (DeSotoEdge.com) and The Olathe Edge (OlatheEdge.com).
The Kansan and Gardner Edge have been in existence for nearly four years. The De Soto Edge and The Olathe Edge were launched in January 2013.
Together, the Websites average over 70,000 different readers each month.
The position is commission only to start out with. The commission rate is 50 percent on all sales and is uncapped. The potential salesperson would also have thousands of leads available, as one-third of all economic activity in the State of Kansas happens in either Johnson County or Wyandotte County. In our four communities alone, there are at least 19,000 businesses.
We sell display advertising, business directory ads (similiar to chamber of commerce memberships) and job postings.
The ideal candidate would have these features:
- At least three years of sales experience, with media sales a plus. Training in digital sales is available.
- The commitment to conduct follow-up calls. Most sales deals are closed on the fourth or fifth try in digital marketing.
- A self-starter with a record of working independently and "grabbing the ball and running with it" when it comes to closing deals.
- A great understanding of today's technology, particularly computers, mobile phones and social media - i.e. Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.
While this is a commission-only position at this time, as our company continues to grow, a negotiated salary could be determined down the road. Though there comes risk with a commission-only position, there is high reward. This is a position that has high-income possibilities, combining our aggressive commission rates and the high leads already available.
Those interested in this position should email a resume, cover letter and references to Director of Marketing/Sales Joel Johns at joel@olatheedge.com and Nick Sloan at nick@olatheedge.com.

Jackson had his flaws as a head coach and there were problems behind the scenes, but the issue I have with firings like these is just like players, coaches improve and grow year by year.
In the first eight years of his coaching career, Doc Rivers failed to win a playoff series in Orlando and Boston. He was on the verge of getting fired in Boston before they landed KG and Ray Allen.
Flash forward to 2014 and Rivers is regarded by many NBA fans as a Top 3-5 coach in the league. The Clips traded a draft pick to land his services.
I'm not saying Jackson's going to win a title, but his first three years as a coach compared to many are not too bad.

I like Kevin Ollie a lot and I think he could be the next great coach, but I'd be hesitant to hire him if I was an NBA team just because of one great tournament run. A lot of average/mediocre coaches have had one great tournament run.
I know Ollie's won a title, but I'd wait at least two years before hiring him.
He re-assigned Brian Scalabrine. You don't just reassign Brian Scalabrine and not expect consequences.

I fully admit that this is based on being a Mizzou fan....but the whole immediate "conference is overrated" argument you hear if the best conference teams aren't traditional powers. There was a lot of talk this year about the SEC being overrated because of Mizzou and Auburn playing for the SEC title. If Auburn was called LSU or Alabama and Mizzou's resume came from a team called Florida or Georgia, there would have been no talk about the SEC being overrated.

I agree, but the one possible angle for a competitor like Saban is winning a national title at three different schools. That would be one of the most unbreakable records in sports. The only guy who'd have a realistic shot at it is Urban Meyer, but he's not leaving Ohio State unless the NFL calls.
While Alabama is a great job and the best program in the country right now, Texas is one of the few jobs where a coach can compete right away. Saban would have that program competing for a national title by year two.

There's a list of 7-10 episodes I really like the best, but I'll just stick with two of them.
1. "Born Free," the Season 1 finale. While I had a feeling Rudy/Brian was the ITK, I did not see the brother twist coming (Didn't read the books). Lithgow's performance as Trinity was the best, but I enjoyed Brian's story better. The interactions between the two brothers as Deb laid on the table was great. Then, Dexter killing Brian and exhibiting emotion for the first time in the show was fantastic too. Everything about that episode was great.
2. "Hello, Dexter Morgan." In my opinion, the ending to the episode is the greatest scene in the series. The cat and mouse game between the two killers was awesome and it was great to see Dexter finally outsmarted by someone. The final few episodes of the season were terrific, but this one was my favorite.
Franklin should wait for the Florida job to get open. I'd hate that he would still be in the SEC, but Florida's the better fit for him IMO.

Not bad, but I actually liked Season 5 and I would only change one big detail: Deb should have pulled the curtain in the season finale and discover who the vigilante killers were. I think that moment started the decline of Dexter, at least compared to the first four seasons.
Deb finding out there would have solved a few of the remaining issues many have with Season 5.
- It gives Lumen a perfectly legitimate reason to bail on Miami rather than "losing" her dark passenger. Deb, who sympathized with the rape victims throughout the season, let's her go for this reason and she disappears forever.
- It doesn't tie everything neatly into a bow. The cliffhanger could be Deb debating on what she does with Dexter.
If I could make one major change, it would have been this one. It also eliminates the Season 6 we got and this alternate Season 6 could have been the final season with perhaps a different ending.

I believe the Drug War should be brought to an end and all drugs should be legalized. The prohibition of drugs creates a lot of the violence we see in larger cities. The federal government has turned the drug trade into a big business. In addition, addicts are often forced to steal or rob homes/businesses to satisfy their habits, creating even more crime and more victims. It's a negative domino effect that's been created by government and law enforcement.
I say legalize drugs, regulate them and use a good chunk of the money to fund drug counselors that can help drug addicts. It's time to stop treating non-violent drug offenders as criminals and treat them as people who have a disease, similar to how we treat alcoholics now.
You would have less violence on the streets, you would have significantly fewer prisons in America and you'd save billions of dollars on a federal program that does not work. And oddly enough, the addicts would be the greatest beneficiary as they could acquire their drugs in a safer manner and not jeopardize the lives of others.
I'm not sure how unpopular this is, but each time I talk to one of my liberal or conservative friends about this issue, I get eye-rolls and strange stares in return.
I would have preferred them trading Miggy Cabrera, personally.
Good point. Thanks for the reminder of that!

At his peak, I'll still take Dan Marino over any other quarterback I've ever seen. The cannon arm, the quick release and the lack of fear in his decision making.
He put up 2010-13 numbers in 1984 and he crushed the production levels of other quarterbacks.
It's sad that this whole "you need a title to vindicate your career" garbage has been shoved down everyone's throats courtesy of ESPN and other sports outlets. Marino only had one 1,000-yard rusher during his Dolphins' career. During his 17 years, Miami only had four Top 10 defenses in that same stretch.
On top of that, he played in an era where the quarterback position wasn't protected to the extent by officials that it is now, and cornerbacks were allowed to be physical with wide receivers.
Rod Woodson remarked that Dan Marino would have thrown for 100,000 career yards if he played in this era. I don't know if that's true, but the point is valid.
He was a great quarterback and has become criminally underrated because of this championship obsession NFL media and fans have.

Michigan State/Kentucky: Just rooting for a great basketball game. I love Tom Izzo and a Kentucky win would make the SEC look good come tournament time, especially if my team is on the bubble.
Duke/Kansas: Duke because they're not Kansas.

While I agree with those who hope Incognito doesn't play another down against, I'd love also to see an angry Ndamukong Suh go against Richie Incognito.

I liked The Phantom Menace and I think some of the complaints lobbed about that film could be applied to the original trilogy as well. Not saying it's better than those three, but the flaws of the classics are overlooked at times.

Jon Stewart and The Daily Show. Don't agree with his politics, but I do respect his ability to ask tough questions --- tougher than those you'll see on Fox News, MSNBC or CNN. I also like Colbert because his character is an excellent parody of that blowhard Bill O'Reilly.
And while I'm on entertainment related issues, politics never enters my mind when it comes to movies or music I consume. I don't care that Tom Hanks and Leo DiCaprio are Democrats: If I'm entertained by their movies, I usually will go see them or check them out on DVD.

This could be a stretch, but how about Thad Matta for one of those jobs, especially the Duke/UNC jobs? While Ohio State's a great program, Duke and North Carolina are a step up. Matta's only 46 and he's been to two Final Fours. He's also a great recruiter.
Corey Tate! Seriously, that was a great game. I miss the old building.

One team I haven't seen mentioned on here is the 1998 North Carolina team with Vince Carter, Antawn Jamison and Ed Cota. That was a great team that I thought would roll Utah in the 1998 Final Four and then beat Kentucky in the finals.
That '97 Kansas team is the best KU team I've ever seen --- and obviously, they've had a lot of them as my Tigers can confirm. Mizzou beating them that year was a borderline miracle.
In this postseason, the Red Sox have won games started by David Price, Max Scherzer twice, Justin Verlander and Adam Wainwright twice. Quite a run.

Whether it's Democrats bashing Ralph Nader or Republicans bashing Robert Sarvis or Ross Perot, it's always pathetic when the two major parties blame a third-party candidate for a loss. The two parties have a monopoly on money and media coverage. They have no disadvantage against a third-party candidate.
Plus, Ronald Reagan crushed Jimmy Carter in 1980 with a moderate Republican (John Anderson) running as an Independent candidate. Also, Harry Truman won in 1948 even with the Democratic Party splitting in three.
If a Democrat or Republican is good enough, he or she wins the day. They need to stop crying in their beer when a third-party candidate does well.

I like and respect the Tea Party of 2009 and 2010. They began as a small government and lower taxes movement that was not necessarily worried about social issues or issues like pot.
But somewhere along the way, some of the Christian conservative types hijacked it. I can't point to when it happened --- maybe during the GOP primary season for the 2012? Now, some in the Tea Party have a litmus test on some issues like abortion and gay marriage.
To me, it started off as a Libertarian grassroots effort that was then hijacked by the Michele Bachmann's, Sarah Palins and Ted Cruz' of the world.
Living in Kansas City during his coaching stint, Todd Haley was never too popular even during the season the Chiefs won the AFC West.

A few:

I'm 28 and I became a Libertarian in my college years. The "all college kids are all wild, hippy liberals" is one of the more inaccurate stereotypes out there. But what turned off students to the GOP was its anti-gay marriage stance and stuff like the Patriot Act and Drug War.

WRITING.TITLE: Libertarianism is spreading on our college campuses. An unusually large number of politically-minded, frustrated students, who refer to themselves as the "liberty movement."

Another thing forgotten is how good the Marlins were and how loaded that roster was.
Pudge Rodriguez was in his prime and he dominated that postseason. Mike Lowell and Derrek Lee were great that year. Oh, and if that line-up wasn't enough, there was a young 20-year-old player by the name of Miggy Cabrera in it. Josh Beckett and Dontrelle Willis (before injury) were great on that staff.
The Cubs still should have won that series, but the Marlins weren't some fluky team that came out of no-where.
Too bad there wasn't a Game 7 for the Cubs to redeem themselves.

Freeman is still just 25 years old. He had a 25-6 touchdown-INT ratio just a few years ago. Heck, even last year, he tossed for 27 touchdowns. He's played for two disastrous head coaches in the NFL (three if you count Ron Prince at K-State). With good coach, he can still be a pretty good quarterback.
Josh Freeman is going to be a steal for Minnesota.

Two that stand out in my lifetime (since '85):
1. Rams vs. Titans: Rams were the classic Cinderella team and Tennessee was under the radar all year due to a 14-2 Jacksonville team in their division.
2. Cardinals vs. Steelers: The Steelers were not a surprise, but the Cardinals were.

Good prediction I was laughed at for: I thought Pittsburgh would finish below .500. Barring a big turnaround, that one's looking decent at the moment.
Bad prediction: I picked the Giants to win the NFC East. Not so much.

Following the history of third parties, there needs to be either a charismatic candidate (Teddy Roosevelt in 1912), big money (Ross Perot) or an issue that unites many Americans (the anti-slavery movement leading to the Republican Party's creation). Big money is invested in the two parties, so that's out. While I respect Gary Johnson and will vote for him in 2016 again, I don't see him being the type to capture America's imagination.
I think Libertarians need to unite and push the issue of the debt. While many issues are important, the debt is something that does concern younger people (I'm 28). One of the dirtiest secrets of the GOP winning the House in 2010 was the fact social issues played little role in the win. The message of "liberty" is nice for those like us, but most Americans don't vote based on philosophy. They're middle of the road. I think Libertarians have to find a way to craft a message of fiscal responsibility that resonates with voters.
Magic Johnson's my favorite player of all-time, but this is good news. Magic's analysis was terrible and Doug Collins was my favorite analysis when he was doing work for NBC. Good upgrade.
While I liked the plot twist and was stunned at the ending, part of me always wished Rita would have found out about Dexter.
Yeah, that year was stacked. Fiennes deserved it, though.
Ralph Fiennes should have won for his portrayal of Amon Goeth in Schindler's List. Fiennes was amazing in that movie.

He outplayed a quarterback who's arguably in the middle of the greatest stretch of quarterback play in NFL history. On another note, if Tom Brady or Peyton Manning were sacked in the manner Romo was on the play before, it's a horse-collar penalty.
Tough break, but Romo played one of the best 10 games I've seen a quarterback play. That last pass doesn't eliminate that.

The 2002 Elite Eight game against Oklahoma. Gilbert, my second favorite Tigers player ever, had his version the John Starks game. Mizzou also missed several free throws and still only lost the game by six points.
If Mizzou wins, they play a very beatable Indiana team with a chance to play for the national title. Plus, it gets the Final Four monkey off of our program's back.
While the '09 Elite Eight loss to UCONN stung, UCONN was a great team and Mizzou had a great run. Losing to a conference rival in an Elite Eight game stings far more.

It's probably one of Pinkel's better road wins. Dominating a decent SEC team on the road is a nice way to open up the conference season and give the football program some good momentum. After a bad season last year, eight to nine wins is doable, which most around the SEC didn't expect.
Murray against Mizzou's secondary terrifies me. Mizzou's offense is good enough to compete against UGA. Bet the over.

Matthews knew about Dexter from the beginning. I thought Season 8 would have revealed that for sure, especially the fact that Matthews consistently helped both Dexter and Deb throughout the series because of his relationship with Harry. I thought they were going down this path when he brought Vogel in on the season opener.
Well, I guess the Democratic Party can create jobs after all.

There were a handful of missed opportunities. I didn't like the cop-out ending in Season 2. Deb should have found out at the end of Season 5. I thought Brian as Dexter's ghost would have been interesting path for the last half of Season 6, but nothing.
However, LaGuerta's death essentially having no impact on Season 8 was unforgivable for the story. Season 7 was a pretty good season IMO with an ending that naturally set-up a shit-storm for Dexter and Deb in Season 8. However, that did not happen. Season 8 should have picked up immediately where Season 7 ended. Instead, we had new characters and an underwhelming "Big Bad" for the final season.
Despite the flaws of the first seven seasons, there was still a great opportunity to end the series on a high note. However, they dropped the ball on LaGuerta's death.
